meaning_mnemonic: This radical has a little head, a curved abdomen, and some long, spindly antennae sticking out from its nose. There's no mistaking it — this little guy is a <radical>shrimp</radical>!
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>idea</radical>.

Legs appear between two lumps of dirt. This is the earth's version of a <radical>womb</radical>. Imagine a tiny baby growing under the ground and then sprouting out, legs first, into the world. Imagine being inside this dirt womb. It's warm and damp. You feel safe.

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>circle</radical>.

Just in case you don't remember this, here's the kanji meaning mnemonic: What's something with <radical>nine</radical> sides? Just add a <radical>drop</radical> and you'll have something that's almost a <kanji>circle</kanji>.
This radical looks just like a <radical>roof</radical>, does it not?
This looks like a bunch of books on a shelf. It's a <radical>bookshelf</radical>!
You see three squares stacked neatly together. On closer inspection, you realize these are boxed <radical>products</radical> waiting to be shipped out.

See that cliff with the white and small bits in it? That's an <radical>original</radical> cliff — we call it that because the white and small bits are actually the bones and fossils of our planet's original inhabitants, buried in the cliffside. (And this one's got a massive sign that says "ORIGINAL," because everything's gotta be a tourist spot these days… sigh.)
You spot a wispy shape flanked by ethereal orbs of flame. Don't be scared — this is just a friendly little <radical>soul</radical> on its way to get reincarnated into a new body.

The radical is the same as the kanji, so it means <radical>body</radical>. 

Just in case you need a refresher, here's the mnemonic again: When your self goes down a slide and hits a barb, it's a painful reminder that you have a body. Sometimes people think their self is just some kind of floating, disembodied consciousness, but getting a barb stuck in oneself while going down a slide will quickly remind one of one's bodily existence.

There's a rice paddy on top of a tree… Figuratively, because trees don't bear rice, they bear <radical>fruit</radical>! Use your imagination, and those four little boxes on top of the tree kind of look like big, ripe fruits — just waiting to be picked.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>hundred</radical>.

It's kind of hard to see, but if you look at this the right way it looks like a food <radical>can</radical>. See the lid being pulled off in the top-left corner? And that horizontal line in the middle? That’s the can's label.
Someone's lying on the ground with his mouth open hoping to swallow up passers-by. This guy's a weirdo — a real <radical>creeper</radical>.

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>good</radical>.

Just in case you don't remember this, here's the kanji meaning mnemonic: A <radical>drop</radical> of water to a <radical>root</radical> is <kanji>good</kanji>. It's good for the roots to grow and live and thrive. And what's good for roots is good for our plants and us humans too.

This is the radical for <radical>canine</radical>, because it looks like a police dog — aka a K-9 — marching around on patrol. You can see its proud little head on the top right, its front legs below crossing as it walks, and a police vest labeled "K-9" strapped around its body. Evil-doers beware — this canine's gonna sniff you out and bring you to justice.

Alternately, you could see the F-shape on the left as a cheerful canine on its hind legs dancing with a drunkard, arm in arm as they sway along together. What a happy canine, dancing like that with a drunk person.
